Literature Review: Sustainable intensification (SI) of agriculture is increasingly recognized as a critical pathway to meet the growing global food demand while minimizing environmental impacts. This literature review focuses on SI strategies within smallholder agricultural systems, particularly in the Global South, where the majority of staple crops are produced. The review synthesizes findings from various studies to identify the most promising SI strategies that have demonstrated favorable impacts on yield, farmer incomes, and environmental sustainability. Among the strategies reviewed, the adoption of improved cultivars stands out for its consistent and significant positive outcomes. Studies have shown that improved cultivars can lead to substantial increases in yield and economic returns for smallholder farmers. For instance, research by Maredia et al. (2018) highlights the role of improved maize varieties in enhancing productivity and resilience to climate variability in Sub-Saharan Africa. Similarly, the work of Walker et al. (2019) underscores the economic benefits of adopting improved rice varieties in South Asia, where increased yields have directly contributed to higher incomes for smallholder farmers. Agroecological practices, such as push-pull systems and the System of Rice Intensification (SRI), have also been identified as effective SI strategies. Push-pull systems, which involve intercropping cereals with repellent plants and planting attractant trap crops, have been shown to significantly reduce pest infestations and increase yields. Khan et al. (2014) provide evidence of the success of push-pull systems in East Africa, where they have led to increased maize and sorghum yields while reducing the need for chemical pesticides. The System of Rice Intensification, which emphasizes changes in the management of plants, soil, water, and nutrients, has also demonstrated remarkable results. Studies by Thakur et al. (2016) and Uphoff (2018) report substantial yield increases and water savings in SRI-adopting regions across Asia and Africa. Despite the promising outcomes of these SI strategies, significant barriers to their adoption and scaling remain. These barriers include limited access to improved seeds, lack of knowledge and training, and financial constraints. Addressing these challenges is crucial for the widespread adoption of SI practices. Innovative approaches, such as participatory breeding programs and farmer field schools, have been proposed as effective means to overcome these barriers. For example, the work of Sperling et al. (2017) highlights the success of participatory breeding in increasing the adoption of improved bean varieties in East Africa. Similarly, Pretty et al. (2018) emphasize the role of farmer field schools in promoting the adoption of sustainable agricultural practices. In conclusion, the literature suggests that the adoption of improved cultivars and agroecological practices such as push-pull systems and the System of Rice Intensification hold considerable promise for sustainable intensification in smallholder agricultural systems. However, overcoming barriers to adoption and scaling these strategies will be essential to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals related to poverty alleviation and food security by 2030.
